cases.title: Music in the Park
cases.text: A student wants to play loud music in a public park. Other people want quiet.
cases.sideA: The student should be allowed to play loud music in the park.
cases.sideB: The student should NOT be allowed to play loud music in the park.

argumentsA.text: The park is a public space for many activities, not only quiet rest.
People who want quiet can move to another area of the park.
There is no rule against playing music in the park.
Music can make the park lively and enjoyable for many visitors.
Some people like listening to music while relaxing.
It’s fun to play loud music.

argumentsB.text: The park is a shared space, so one person’s music should not disturb many others.
People use parks to rest and enjoy nature, and loud music prevents this.
Noise spreads far and affects people who did not choose to hear it.
Rules are needed in public spaces to protect everyone’s comfort.
Many people go to parks to escape city noise.

cases.title: Club Room
cases.text: Two school clubs want the same classroom after school. Only one club can use it.
cases.sideA: The school should give the room to the bigger club.
cases.sideB: The school should make the clubs share the room.

argumentsA.text: More students can use the room if the bigger club gets it.
The bigger club needs more space to practice safely and properly.
Using the room for the bigger club makes the best use of school resources.
If the room is always shared, practice time will be too short for both clubs.
The school should choose the option that helps the most students.

argumentsB.text: Both clubs are school activities and should be treated equally.
Sharing teaches cooperation and respect between students.
No club should have special power just because it is bigger.
If one club always wins, the smaller club may disappear.
The school should make rules that are fair for all clubs.

cases.title: Curfew
cases.text: A city wants a 9 p.m. curfew for 16-year-olds. Some people agree. Some people disagree.
cases.sideA: The city should NOT have a curfew for 16-year-olds.
cases.sideB: The city SHOULD have a curfew for 16-year-olds.

argumentsA.text: Most 16-year-olds follow the law, so a curfew punishes many for the actions of a few.
Young people may need to travel for jobs, clubs, or family reasons.
Freedom helps adolescents learn responsibility and independence.
Police time should be used for serious crime, not checking teenagers’ ages.
A curfew does not solve the real causes of crime.

argumentsB.text: A curfew can reduce the risk of young people becoming victims of crime at night.
Late at night, it is harder for police to protect minors.
Clear rules help parents and police work together to protect adolescents.
Fewer young people on the streets at night can reduce noise and trouble.
Society has a duty to protect minors more than adults.
People feel worried when teens are outside late at night.
